thread.title: 14 Things That Make New Parents Say "Babies Are Weird"
thread.title_full: 14 Things That Make New Parents Say "Babies Are Weird"

author: Krista Torres
title: 14 Things That Make New Parents Say "Babies Are Weird"
text:
View this image ›
ABC This sticky, black stool is called meconium. Luckily, it will only last a few days after birth.
ID: 10348127 2. You will notice the soft spot on your baby’s head pulsate. View this image ›
youtube.com TOTALLY NORMAL. It’s because the soft spot is directly over blood vessels in the brain.
ID: 10348166 3. You will also wonder why your baby doesn’t have tears when they cry. View this image ›
youtube.com This is because their tear ducts aren’t fully developed yet. They will develop within the first few months.
ID: 10348365 4. You might see thin, soft hair all over your baby. View this image ›
Comedy Central These hairs — called lanugo — usually disappear in utero, but some babies are born with it. Don’t worry, though. It will soon go away.
ID: 10349782 5. Your baby will actually lose weight their first week after birth. View this image ›
CW Don’t worry, they gain it back within the next few weeks.
ID: 10348178 6. Your baby’s umbilical cord might not fall off for a few weeks. View this image ›
Netflix But, if you keep it dry, it will fall off faster!
ID: 10348157 7. You will also notice your baby doesn’t have kneecaps. View this image ›
Paramount This is because a newborn baby’s kneecaps are made of cartilage. In time, though, hard bone will form.
ID: 10349433 8. You can try to make your baby smile or coo, but they won’t. View this image ›
NBC These responses don’t happen until your baby is about six weeks. However, it is still important for you to talk to your baby because it helps their brain develop.
ID: 10348150 9. Your baby will sleep about 16 hours a day – but only in one to two hour increments. View this image ›
yahoo.com Around six months old, babies start sleeping longer during the night. But until then, caffeine is your new best friend.
ID: 10349318 10. Your baby may have very visible veins on their head and face. View this image ›
CW Parts of your baby’s skull have not fully fused together yet, so it makes veins and arteries more visible.
ID: 10349525 11. You’ll have to feed your baby every two to three hours because their stomach only holds about 1-2 teaspoons. View this image ›
Bravo You can’t go anywhere without a bottle or boob.
ID: 10348201 12. You’ll only get a reaction from your baby when you put your face really close to theirs. View this image ›
E! Newborns can only see around a foot or so in front of their face. Thankfully, after about a month, they will be able to focus on objects further away.
ID: 10348258 13. You may notice your baby has tons of dandruff, aka cradle cap. View this image ›
youtube.com This dry flakiness is common and typically goes away after the first month or so.
ID: 10349252 14. And, of course, your baby will projectile vomit/poop on you. View this image ›
Rolling Stone Get used to it!
ID: 10348832
